paragraphs.text:
%md

# Using ML to define an astrometrically clean sample of stars

   Follows Gaia EDR3 performance verification paper DPACP-81 (Smart et al.) in classifying astrometric solutions as good or bad
   via supervised ML. Employs a Random Forrest classifier plus appropriately defined training sets - see

   https://gaia.esac.esa.int/dpacsvn/DPAC/docs/DpacPublications/DR3PerformanceVerification/DPACP-81/main_submitted2308.pdf

   (DPAC password protected) for further details. The work flow implemented here follows closely that described in Section 2, "GCNS Generation"
   (GCNS = Gaia Catalogue of Nearby Stars) and is designed to clean up a 100pc (= nearby) sample.

   Presently implemented for Gaia DR2; deploy and check this implementation against GEDR3 when released - it should reproduce what's in the paper.

msg.data:
Using ML to define an astrometrically clean sample of stars

Follows Gaia EDR3 performance verification paper DPACP-81 (Smart et al.) in classifying astrometric solutions as good or bad
via supervised ML. Employs a Random Forrest classifier plus appropriately defined training sets - see

https://gaia.esac.esa.int/dpacsvn/DPAC/docs/DpacPublications/DR3PerformanceVerification/DPACP-81/main_submitted2308.pdf

(DPAC password protected) for further details. The work flow implemented here follows closely that described in Section 2, “GCNS Generation”
(GCNS = Gaia Catalogue of Nearby Stars) and is designed to clean up a 100pc (= nearby) sample.

Presently implemented for Gaia DR2; deploy and check this implementation against GEDR3 when released - it should reproduce what’s in the paper.

paragraphs.text:
%spark.pyspark

# this is the set of astrometric features to be used. In reality several iterations of this workflow might be required with an expanded set, and some figure-of-merit,
# e.g. Gini index, would be used to select those most important to the RF classification - cf. Table A.1 in the GCNS paper.
astrometric_features = [
    'parallax_error', 
    'parallax_over_error',
    'astrometric_sigma5d_max',
    'pmra_error',
    'pmdec_error',
    'astrometric_excess_noise',
    #'ipd_gof_harmonic_amplitude',
    #'ruwe',                             TODO: reinstate all at GEDR3 !!!
    'visibility_periods_used',
    'pmdec',
    'pmra',
    #'ipd_frac_odd_win',
    #'ipd_frac_multi_peak',
    'astrometric_gof_al',
    #'scan_direction_strength_k2',
    'parallax_pmdec_corr'
]
# ... the last two are included to cross check against the Gini index results presented in the paper.

# quick mode: set an additional precicate filter on random_index here to limit to 1% or 0.1% sampling etc:
quick_filter = ' AND MOD(random_index, 10) = 0'
# ... to switch this off, simply specify an empty string.

# reformat the above attribute list into an SQL comma-separated select string
features_select_string = ('%s, '*(len(astrometric_features) - 1) + '%s ')%tuple(astrometric_features)
#print (features_select_string)

# photometric consistency predicate - e.g. Evans et al. (2018), Babusiaux et al. (2018) for DR2:
photometric_consistency_filter = " AND phot_bp_rp_excess_factor BETWEEN 1.0 + (0.03 * POW(bp_rp, 2.0)) AND 1.3 + (0.06 * POW(bp_rp, 2.0))"

# define the data source
gs_df = sqlContext.read.parquet("/data/gaia/*.parquet")

# register as SQL-queryable 
gs_df.createOrReplaceTempView("gaia_source")

%spark.pyspark

# clear any previously cached data in the context (cells may be executed in any order, and out-dated by changes from here onwards)
sqlContext.clearCache()

# a conservative selection of everything that COULD be within 100pc, including things with measured 
# distances putting them outside the 100pc horizon when their true distances are within, and also including 
# loads of spurious chaff with the wheat of course, plus bad things with significant, unphysical parallaxes:
raw_sources_df = spark.sql("SELECT source_id, random_index, phot_g_mean_mag, phot_bp_rp_excess_factor, bp_rp, g_rp, parallax, ra, dec, b " + features_select_string + "FROM gaia_source WHERE ABS(parallax) > 8.0")

# cache it for speedy access below (all subsequent samples are derived from this):
raw_sources_df.cache()

# register as SQL-queryable
raw_sources_df.createOrReplaceTempView("raw_sources")

raw_sources_df.count()
# (cf. GEDR3: 1,211,740 sources)

%spark.pyspark

# plot an observational Hertzsprung-Russell diagram (aka colour / absolute magnitude diagram) for the unclassified sample to show the problem,
# include the photometric consistency filter to show the problem is astrometric in addition to photometric
unclassified_camd_df = spark.sql("SELECT phot_g_mean_mag + 5.0*LOG10(parallax/100.0) AS m_g, g_rp FROM raw_sources WHERE parallax > +8.0" + quick_filter)# + photometric_consistency_filter)

import matplotlib.pyplot as plot
plot.figure(0, figsize = (6.0, 9.7))
x = list(unclassified_camd_df.select("g_rp").toPandas()["g_rp"])
y = list(unclassified_camd_df.select("m_g").toPandas()["m_g"])
plot.scatter(x, y, marker = ".", s = 1)
plot.ylim(21.0, -3.0)
plot.ylabel("Stellar brightness (absolute G magnitude) -->", fontsize = 16)
plot.xlabel("<-- Stellar temperature (G - RP magnitude)", fontsize = 16)
plot.show()

msg.data:
The problem: while we see astrophysically interesting locii in this diagram, the lower right (cool, low temperature) regime
is dominated by systematic errors (not random uncertainties - the data should be equally precise in all parts of this data
space) that contaminate the raw sample. We wish to clean the sample to obtain high reliability

  • without compromising completeness;
  • utilising quality features in the raw catalogue;
  • and efficiently;

i.e. without endless iterations of manual, subjective, axis-parallel and arbitrary cuts on available catalogue attributes. A neat solution to this is to use supervised ML. In the Gaia EDR3 performance verification paper “Gaia Catalogue of Nearby Stars” (Smart, Sarro, Rybicki, et al. 2020) we use a Random Forest of decision trees on selected features having first defined a training set based on the data itself.

Note that plotting the intrinsic brightness of a star as above requires determination of the distance to it along with a measurement of it’s apparent brightness. Stellar distance determination is a fundamental goal of the Gaia mission and is achieved via measurement of the stellar parallax, the apparent “wobble” in angular position exhibited by all stars as seen from our (annually changing) view point in the solar system. The sample plotted above is selected for parallax > 8 milliarcseconds (mas) which corresponds to a distance within 125 parsecs (since a star at distance 1 parsec exhibits a parallax of 1 arcsecond; parsec = “parallax arcsecond”; 1 parsec is around 3.3 light-years).

An 8 mas training set of “good” examples is “cleaned” of highly probable spurious sources using independent photometric criteria (i.e. we require consistency of optical and infrared colours). The “bad” examples are selected having (unphysical) parallax < -8 mas, i.e. using parallax measurements that are formally highly significant, yet obviously spurious. Under the assumption of normally distributed uncertainties on the parallax measurements, this bad sample should be representative of the corresponding spurious measurements having parallax > 8 mas that contaminate the parallax-selected sample and, in particular, create the contamination illustrated in the plot above.

paragraphs.text:
%spark.pyspark

# bad training data: negative parallaxes:
all_bad_training_df = spark.sql("SELECT " + features_select_string + " FROM raw_sources WHERE parallax < -8.0" + quick_filter)

# good training data: first define rough positional cuts to exclude crowded regions at low Gaialctic latitude and inside the Large and Small Magellanic Clouds (Luri et al. 2020):
low_galactic_latitude_filter = " AND ABS(b) > 25.0"
smc_filter = " AND (dec < -80.0 OR dec > -65.0 OR (ra < 350.0 AND ra > +40.0))"
lmc_filter = " AND (dec < -80.0 OR dec > -55.0 OR ra < 40.0 OR ra > 120.0)"
all_good_training_df = spark.sql("SELECT " + features_select_string + " FROM raw_sources WHERE parallax > + 8.0 AND ABS(b) > 25.0 AND  " + photometric_consistency_filter + quick_filter + low_galactic_latitude_filte + smc_filter + lmc_filter)

%spark.pyspark

# get the optical and infrared (2MASS) photometry for the set of examples of good astrometric solutions (uses GACS call-out for DPAC crossmatch at GDR2)
#
# TODO: replace this with an internal GEDR3/2MASS match (using AXS) when deployed.

import warnings
warnings.filterwarnings("ignore")
from astroquery.utils.tap.core import TapPlus
gaia = TapPlus(url="https://gea.esac.esa.int/tap-server/tap")

adql_query = "SELECT g.source_id, " + \
             "phot_g_mean_mag - phot_rp_mean_mag AS g_rp, " + \
             "phot_g_mean_mag - j_m AS g_j, " + \
             "phot_g_mean_mag - h_m AS g_h, " + \
             "phot_g_mean_mag - ks_m AS g_ks, " + \
             "phot_g_mean_mag + 5.0*log10(parallax/100.0) AS mg, " + features_select_string + \
             "FROM gaiadr2.gaia_source AS g, gaiadr2.tmass_best_neighbour AS x, gaiadr1.tmass_original_valid AS t " + \
             "WHERE g.source_id = x.source_id AND x.tmass_oid = t.tmass_oid" + quick_filter + \
             " AND parallax > 8.0 AND ABS(g.b) > 25.0" + \
             " AND 0=CONTAINS(POINT('ICRS', g.ra, g.dec), CIRCLE('ICRS', 12.80, -73.15, 11.0))" + \
             " AND 0=CONTAINS(POINT('ICRS', g.ra, g.dec), CIRCLE('ICRS', 81.28, -69.78, 20.0))"
# ... last three predicates exclude low Galactic latitudes and the Magellanic Clouds (Luri et al. 2020).

# execute the query
job = gaia.launch_job_async(adql_query)
results = job.get_results()
len(results)
# direct execution via the GACS UI yields a count of 291,394 in 2min

paragraphs.text:
%spark.pyspark

# convenience reformatting from astropy.table.table.Table (?!) to Pandas:
#pandas_results = results.to_pandas()
#print(results.columns)

# numpy vectors of the optical/IR photometry:
import numpy as np
gmrp = np.array(results["g_rp"])
gmj = np.array(results["g_j"])
gmh = np.array(results["g_h"])
gmks = np.array(results["g_ks"])
gabs = np.array(results["mg"])

gidx = ((gabs > 15.0) & (gabs < 16.0))

# plot a colour-colour diagram of an absolute magnitude slice:
plot.figure(1, figsize = (8.0, 8.0))
plot.scatter(gmrp[gidx], gmks[gidx], marker = ".", s = 1)
plot.xlabel("Optical colour (G - RP)", fontsize = 16)
plot.ylabel("Optical / infrared colour (G - Ks)", fontsize = 16)
plot.show()

# to a Spark partitioned dataframe TODO may not be needed in final implementation
#photometry_df = spark.createDataFrame(pandas_results)

# Sanity checks:
#photometry_df.schema
#photometry_df.rdd.getNumPartitions()
#photometry_df.show()

%spark.pyspark

plot.figure(3, figsize = (6.0, 9.7))
plot.scatter(gmj, gabs, marker = ".", s = 1)
plot.ylim(21.0, -3.0)
plot.ylabel("Stellar brightness (absolute G magnitude) -->", fontsize = 16)
plot.xlabel("<-- Stellar temperature (G - RP magnitude)", fontsize = 16)
plot.show()

%spark.pyspark

# TODO: refine the raw crossmatch photometry selection using GMM (WD, Red Clump and Giant Branch) and 5d Principal Curve (Main Sequence)
# select them all for now:
good_ast_df = photometry_df.select(astrometric_features)
good_ast_df.show()

# record the number of good training solutions:
good_ast_count = len(results)

%spark.pyspark

# bad astrometric solutions: negative (unphysical!) parallaxes at high significance where
# the parallax threshold corresponds to that on the +ve (physical) side of the parallax distribution
all_bad_ast_df = spark.sql("SELECT source_id, random_index, " + features_select_string + "FROM gaia_source WHERE parallax < -8.0")

# cache for for subsequent steps prior to count (aids performance... IIUC)
all_bad_ast_df.cache()
all_bad_ast_count = all_bad_ast_df.count()

# N.B. make a selection the same size as the good training set based on size of smaller (good) data set and count of all available bads
filter_factor = int(all_bad_ast_count / good_ast_count)
bad_ast_df = all_bad_ast_df.where("MOD(random_index, %d) = 0"%(filter_factor))
bad_ast_df.count()
# (cf. GEDR3: 512,288 sources)

%spark.pyspark

# first balance the good and bad samples: need the same number in both. The good sample will be the smaller of the two, 
# so define a bad sample the same size as that TODO


# define training (67%) and test (33%) samples TODO



# map the training data frames onto new RDD consisting of appropriately labeled [sic] LabelPoint objects

from pyspark.mllib.regression import LabeledPoint

# for the bad (label = 0) training set
bad_training_rdd = bad_ast_df.drop('source_id').rdd.map(lambda row: LabeledPoint(0, [x for x in row]))

# and for the good (label = 1) set, need to drop also the photometry (these must not be used as features - see GCNS paper)
good_training_rdd = good_ast_df.drop('source_id', 'gminusj', 'Mg', 'Mj', 'Mh', 'Mk').rdd.map(lambda row: LabeledPoint(1, [x for x in row]))

# concatenate:
training_rdd = good_training_rdd.union(bad_training_rdd)

# manual type safety check (!) - h:
#type(training_rdd.collect()[0])

%spark.pyspark

# This cell does the business, given the data and training sets. Follows the example Python code at 
# https://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/api/python/pyspark.mllib.html#pyspark.mllib.tree.RandomForest

from pyspark.mllib.tree import RandomForest

# instantiate a trained RF classifier, seeded for repeatability at this stage:
model = RandomForest.trainClassifier(training_rdd, numClasses = 2, categoricalFeaturesInfo = {}, featureSubsetStrategy = 3, numTrees = 100, impurity = 'gini', seed=42)
# data should be an RDD of LabeledPoint, say 0 = bad/negative, 1 = good/positive: [LabeledPoint(0, [list of features of a bad example]), LabeledPoint(1, [list of features of a good example]), ... ]
# type(model) = RandomForestModel that can be used for prediction.
# TODOs:
# - DPACP-81 example "The random Forest consists of 5000 decision trees built by selecting amongst three randomly selected predictors at each split." 
#   ... need to check that featureSubsetStrategy = 3 option covers this and is appropriate to the task.

# default featureSubsetStrategy:
# Benchmarks: numTrees = 10; 1% sampling: trains in 7m 09s 
#                       100 10          :           9m 24s !
#                      5000 100         :

model.numTrees()

model.totalNumNodes()

#print(model)

#print(model.toDebugString())

paragraphs.text:
%spark.pyspark

# classify based on the above trained model:
classifications = model.predict(rdd).collect()

%spark.pyspark

# test what the hell is going on:
from pyspark.mllib.regression import LabeledPoint
from pyspark.mllib.tree import RandomForest
data = [
     LabeledPoint(0.0, [0.0]),
     LabeledPoint(0.0, [1.0]),
     LabeledPoint(1.0, [2.0]),
     LabeledPoint(1.0, [3.0])
]

model = RandomForest.trainClassifier(sc.parallelize(data), 2, {}, 3, seed=42)
model.numTrees()

model.totalNumNodes()

print(model)

print(model.toDebugString())

model.predict([2.0])

model.predict([0.0])

rdd = sc.parallelize([[3.0], [1.0]])
model.predict(rdd).collect()
